Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, my phone buzzing with another message from Alex. Our argument from last night still echoed in my mind—sharp words, accusations, the threat of breaking up hanging between us. I knew he expected me to reach out, to try to fix things, to show that I cared enough to fight for us. But as I scrolled through the pharmacy newsletter, my mind kept drifting. There was a new drug release, and I needed to understand its interactions before my shift ended. My manager always expected us to be on top of these updates, and I couldn’t afford to fall behind. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on the article, but Alex’s words kept flashing across my screen. I felt torn—should I put down the newsletter and call him, or keep reading so I wouldn’t let my team down? The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I sat frozen, unable to choose which part of myself to let down first.
